oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Dekalb County enrollment in state militia per Governor Andrew Johnson's proclamation
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Tennessee -- Miltia; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Registers, lists, etc.; Johnson, Andrew, 1808-1875; Tennessee -- Office of the Adjutant General
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Oversize 3-page form, printed with handwritten entries reflecting District 9, Dekalb County enrollment in state militia; has 81 entries for white males and 7 entries for "Cullard" [black] males. The call-up was brought about by the Militia Enrollment Proclamation, September 13, 1864, of Governor Andrew Johnson, seeking to ascertain the number and location of anyone capable of military service if needed, and requiring a separate sheet for black enrollment.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Tennessee -- Adjutant-General's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: With Federal troops at the front during Sherman's Atlanta Campaign, the Governor and the military sought security, given increasing Confederate cavalry and guerrilla raids. Johnson chose to call up the militia through a governor's proclamation. The Militia Enrollment Proclamation made justices of the peace responsible for overseeing the sign-up of males between 18 and 50. This marked the first time in the state's history that African Americans were to be included as members of the militia.
